EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Dreyer¿s Grand Ice Cream uses anhydrous ammonia for refrigeration of retail quantities of ice cream products for wholesale distribution.  Ammonia is the only hazardous chemical used at this facility that is subject to the CalARP program or federal RMP requirements.

This facility recognizes the hazards associated with the use of highly hazardous chemicals.  As a reflection of our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws and regulations, we submit this plan to address the hazards inherent with the use of ammonia.  Our program addresses safety precautions regarding the handling and operation of this covered system as well as proper training for those who operate and maintain the system.  The company training policy requires that all employees will be properly trained for a job position before assignment to that job.

Our accidental release prevention program is clearly defined by the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Program for this facility.  This prevention program follows industry-recommended standards for preventing unnecessary human exposures and reducing the threat to the health of our employees as well as to members of the community and the surrounding area.  Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle these chemicals, the safety devices inherent in the design of this facility and its processes, and the training that we provide our personnel.  This Plan is updated as required by law.

Our Emergency Action Plan (EAP) details the response this facility will take as a result of an uncontrolled release of ammonia.  The Plan includes procedures for notification of the local emergency responders.  This EAP also includes a specific protocol for responding to an ammonia release and assigns an Emergency Coordinator to implement the response.  This Plan is current and updated as required by law and conforms to the requirements for an Emergency Action Plan

as per 29 CFR 1910.38.

This facility has also coordinated with the local emergency responders and will maintain close contact to ensure that the responders are familiar with the system and with the general safety and accidental release program at our plant.

It is the policy of this facility to devote the time, energy, and capital toward maintaining prevention and response programs appropriate to the inherent dangers with the use of hazardous chemicals.

 
THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The Stationary Source

 The Dreyer¿s Grand Ice Cream Distribution Center is located at 1351 DuPont Court in Manteca, California at the end of DuPont Court.  The facility lies approximately 500 yards west of State Highway 99 and 500 yards north of State Highway 120 near the intersection of the two highways.  The facility is situated in an area comprised primarily of light industrial facilities, commercial and office areas, some agricultural lands, and residential areas.

This facility stores ice cream products for distribution under approximately 98,000 square feet of total warehouse space, with approximately 70,000 square feet of refrigerated space.  The remaining areas include office areas, the control room, and the engine room.  There is no manufacturing at this facility.

The distribution center will employ 65 people and will operate six days per week.  The hours of operation will vary from a two-shift schedule 17 hours per day to a full 24-hour operation, depending on the season.

The following history was extracted from the Dreyer¿s Inc. website (www.dreyers.com):

DREYER¿S HISTORY

Dreyer¿s American Dream

William Dreyer began his love affair with ice cream in 1906 when, as a galley boy, he earned the prestigious job of making a frozen dessert to celebrate his German ship¿s arrival in America.  After a brief career making ice cream in New York, he settled in northern California and began a 20-year apprenticeship with ice cream makers such as National I

ce Cream Company and Peerless Ice Cream.

Dreyer opened his own ice creamery in Visalia, California, and won First Prize at the 1921 Pacific Slope Dairy Show.  Over the next two decades, he taught ice cream courses at the University of California and served as an officer in the California Dairy Industries Association. 

Grand Beginnings

Dreyer found a business partner and kindred spirit in renowned candy-maker Joseph Edy after moving to Oakland, California.  Dreyer¿s ice cream expertise and Edy¿s candy-making acumen created a winning combination. Their small ice cream factory on Grand Avenue quickly became a gathering place.  ¿Grand¿ has been part of the company name ever since ¿ both as a reminder of the company¿s birthplace on Grand Avenue and a declaration of the outstanding quality of their ice cream.
The Birth of Rocky Road

At the time of Rocky Road¿s birth in 1929, almost all ice cream was made in three flavors ¿ vanilla, chocolate, and strawberry ¿ and was always served as sundaes.  Dreyer added walnuts (later replaced with almonds) to his chocolate ice cream and, using his wife¿s sewing shears, cut marshmallows into bite-sized pieces to make the first batch of Rocky Road. Dreyer and Edy picked a flavor name to give folks something to smile about in the face of the Great Depression.  Rocky Road became America¿s first blockbuster flavor and remains one of the best-selling flavors of all time.  Dreyer invented a number of other flavors that are still made today, including Toasted Almond and Peppermint Stick.

Change & Growth

In 1946, William Dreyer¿s only son joined the ice cream business and Joe Edy focused on his candy business.  In July 1947, Edy and Dreyer officially dissolved their partnership.  The Dreyers opened a state-of-the-art ice cream plant in 1948.  In 1963, Dreyer¿s son sold the company to his key officers ¿ Al Wolff, Bob Boone and Ken Cook.  Dreyer remained active in the company until his death in 1975. 

The company was purchased in 1977 by

T. Gary Rogers and W. F. (Rick) Cronk.  Under Rogers¿ and Cronk¿s direction, Dreyer¿s Grand Ice Cream expanded its distribution to become the leading manufacturer, marketer and distributor of packaged ice cream in the United States.

In 2003, the Company merged with Nestlé Ice Cream Company, LLC (NICC) to form Dreyer¿s Grand Ice Cream Holdings, Inc.  After 26 years in the ice cream business, Dreyer¿s President W.F. (Rick) Cronk retired in 2003 from the business he did so much to build.

A year later, Dreyer¿s introduced its resoundingly successful Slow Churned¿ Grand Light® Ice Cream with half the fat, one-third fewer calories and all the flavor found in full-fat premium ice cream.  A few months later, Dreyer¿s acquired Silhouette Brands, producers of outstanding low-fat and low carb snacks marketed under the Skinny Cow® and Skinny Carb® brands.

Today, Dreyer¿s Grand Ice Cream is a $1 billion company.  In honor of both founders, the company¿s premium products are marketed under the Dreyer¿s brand throughout the western states and the Edy¿s brand throughout the remainder of the United States.  Internationally, the Dreyer¿s brand extends to select markets in the Far East and the Edy¿s brand to the Caribbean and South America.  

Dreyer¿s Holdings, with its subsidiaries, manufactures and distributes a full spectrum of ice cream and frozen dessert products.  Brands of frozen dessert products currently manufactured and distributed by Dreyer¿s in the United States include Grand, Grand Light®, Slow Churned¿, Häagen-Dazs®, Nestlé® Drumstick®, Nestlé Crunch®, Butterfinger®, Toll House®, Carnation®, Push-Up®, Dole®, Homemade, Fruit Bars, Starbucks®, Silhouette®, Skinny Cow®, Skinny Carb Bar¿ and Healthy Choice®.

Living up to its ¿Grand¿ name is a driving passion at Dreyer¿s.  William Dreyer and Joseph Edy instilled that passion in 1928, and it lives on today.

Regulated Substance Handled

This facility utilizes anhydrous ammonia as a heat transfer fluid in the plant refrige

ration system.  The system is a single-stage, multi-suction, economized mechanical refrigeration system that utilizes recirculated liquid feed to evaporator coils.  Cooling is required for the 10°F Shipping Dock and for the -20°F freezer.  The system charge is 13,000 lbs.

One high-temperature screw compressor provides suction and compression for the high temperature cooling, while two low-temperature screw compressors serve the low-temperature cooling requirements.  A swing screw compressor can back-up either the high-temperature or low-temperature requirements as needed.

The heat of compression in the high-pressure compressor discharge is removed in the evaporative condenser.  The condenser drains high-pressure liquid to the thermosiphon / high-pressure receiver for screw compressor cooling and recirculator package liquid ammonia as required.  Liquid from the high-temperature recirculator (HTR) and the low-temperature recirculator (LTR) is pumped to the evaporators as needed for cooling at the dock and in the freezer.

RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

This facility complies with the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program and OSHA¿s Process Safety Management (PSM) Program.  Key prevention steps taken by this facility to maintain safety are outlined in the PSM Program.  These include the description of all system and equipment information, process hazard analysis, operator training, contractor qualification, operating procedures, pre-startup safety review, hot work permitting, management of change, mechanical integrity, incident investigation, compliance audits, and emergency response.

Those who operate, maintain, or monitor the system will be trained to understand the principles of ammonia refrigeration and ammonia properties, an understanding of the process equipment and proper operating and maintenance procedures, recognition of abnormal conditions and the steps to correct deviations, and emergency shutdown procedures as appropriate to the level of involvement each employee will have with the process.  Contractors that perform maintenance or that design changes to the system will be qualified by the facility based upon their experience and safety record before being selected to provide such services.

The general safety program includes hazardous communication, forklift operation, first aid, emergency response, and additional programs as necessary to maintain a safe operation.

THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

This process is a new installation and, therefore, has no history at this time.

THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Employees are trained to understand the requirements of the Emergency Action Plan.  The Emergency Action Plan includes release notification for emergency responders and the procedures for evacuation.  The Emergency Coordinator implements the response in coordination with the local emergency responders (i.e. the fire department).  It is the policy and practice to conduct evacuation drills twice per year.

LANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was performed as required prior to initial startup of the system.  The PHA team developed a list of recommendations to improve safety by reducing potential hazards of the process.  All recommendations were implemented, deemed unnecessary since no improvements to safety would result, or planned for implementation at a later date.  Upcoming events include:

1.  Training of employees to conduct daily monitoring of system conditions
2.  Minor modifications to PLC control logic for pumps
